unnormalised: Someone just asked me about linear algebra, and honestly, my head started spinning a bit! I remember struggling through it back in my B.Tech days at IIT Delhi. Prof. Sharma was brilliant, no doubt, but sometimes the concepts felt like trying to solve a Rubik's cube blindfolded. We spent hours on topics like eigenvalues and eigenvectors, trying to figure out how to apply them. I think I finally got a grasp on matrix operations, solving systems of equations with 3 or 4 variables, though Cramer's rule felt like cheating, didn't it?

unnormalised: One thing that really helped was visualizing the transformations. Seeing how a matrix could rotate or scale a vector made things click. Also, the textbook problems were a killer! Especially chapter 6, questions 12-20. I also remember spending ages trying to understand Gaussian elimination - seems simple now, but back then it was a nightmare. We even had one exam question that involved a 5x5 matrix – absolute torture.
